docs.lead_paragraph: More than seven years after the broccoli-bashing presidency of George Bush, vegetables and fruit still have not caught on with the public, despite the health benefits. Fewer than one-fourth of Americans eat the five daily servings of fruit and vegetables recommended by federal health officials and the National Cancer Institute, a survey has found.

headline.main: Americans Still Pass Up the Vegetables

docs.abstract: Survey finds under 25 percent of Americans eat five daily servings of fruit and vegetables recommended by federal health officials and National Cancer Institute; report is published in American Journal of Public Health; photo (M)
docs.snippet: More than seven years after the broccoli-bashing presidency of George Bush, vegetables and fruit still have not caught on with the public, despite the health benefits.    Fewer than one-fourth of Americans eat the five daily servings of fruit and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, 180,000 American men will suddenly learn this year that they have prostate cancer, and what makes their decisions about treatment so difficult is that doctors do not know which one is most effective. Better information about survival and side effects may come from trials under way in Canada, Sweden and the United States, but not for several years. Until then, patients must rely on limited information, and wide variations in practice will occur.

headline.main: Exploring the Enigma of Prostate Therapies

docs.abstract: Lawrence K Altman article on prostate cancer treatments notes doctors still do not know which treatment is most effective; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The much-reviled oxidant, also known as the free radical, has a new defender. The chemical, which occurs naturally in the body, has long been linked to cancer and other illnesses. And antioxidants, including those found in high concentrations in fruits like the pomegranate, have been assumed to be of potential value.

headline.main: A Good Word for the Maligned Oxidant

docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers find much-reviled oxidants, long linked to illnesses, seem to play vital role in repairing blood-vessel damage that can lead to heart attacks; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ulcerative colitis, a serious disease in which the lining of the colon and rectum become inflamed, causing severe pain, appears to be worsened by long-term stress, a new study has found. Doctors have long theorized that stress can play a role in the disease, but have never been able to prove it, said the researchers, writing in the May issue of The American Journal of Gastroenterology.

headline.main: Painful Colon Disease Is Linked to Stress

docs.abstract: New study finds ulcerative colitis, disease in which lining of colon and rectum become inflamed, seems to be worsened by long-term stress (S)
docs.snippet: Ulcerative colitis, a serious disease in which the lining of the colon and rectum become inflamed, causing severe pain, appears to be worsened by long-term stress, a new study has found.    Doctors have long theorized that stress can play a role in...

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, it has seemed almost axiomatic: to know if someone has high blood pressure, just look at the figure for the patient's diastolic pressure (the ''80,'' for example, in 120/80). The upper, or systolic, figure, was practically ignored. But federal health officials said last week that this belief, common among many doctors, is wrong -- dangerously so, in many cases. Systolic blood pressure, health officials said, is a reliable general sign of hypertension and as people get to middle age and beyond, it is the best reliable indicator.
docs.abstract: Federal health officials say doctors treating high blood pressure are wrong to consider only patient's diastolic pressure, while practically ignoring upper, or systolic, figure; say systolic pressure is reliable general sign of hypertension and is best reliable indicator in people who are middle age or older (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1960's, researchers began diagnosing hereditary disorders by examining the amniotic fluid surrounding the fetuses carried by pregnant women considered at high risk. By the 1970's, amniocentesis had become available to women of advanced maternal age. Now, amniocentesis is routine. In testing, about three tablespoons of amniotic fluid with discarded fetal cells are withdrawn from the uterus, cultured in the lab and inspected for abnormalities.

headline.main: When Fetal Tests Weigh Heavy on Prospective Parents

docs.abstract: Edited transcripts of interviews conducted by Prof Rayna Rapp with pregnant women who have used amniocentesis over last 10 years to test fetus for birth defects; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An outburst of anger sometimes prompts the plaintive response, ''Don't have a heart attack!'' There may be something to that advice, it turns out. A study that looked at almost 13,000 people over six years found that those who were most prone to anger were about 2.5 times as likely to have heart attacks or sudden cardiac deaths as their calmer counterparts.

headline.main: When Anger Sets Off Heart Attacks

docs.abstract: Six-year study of some 13,000 people who appeared to be free of heart disease finds those most prone to anger are 2.5 times as likely to have heart attacks or sudden cardiac deaths than calmer counterparts; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Around the besieged provincial legislature building here, the din of banging pots died away, candles flickered in the evening breeze and protesters began singing their hymn: ''Oh Medicare.'' ''Long live our plan, keep it free from greed,'' hundreds of voices sang into the spring night. Referring to the health care plan for all Canadians, they sang, ''Oh Medicare, we stand on guard for thee.''

headline.main: A Crossroads in Canadian Health Care

docs.abstract: Bill offered by Alberta Premier Ralph Klein to allow government reimbursement of private clinics for same surgical procedures performed in government hospitals has spurred demonstrations against perceived threat to Canada's government-run national health plan; dogged loyalty of Albertans to public health system surprises politicians in conservative province; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, obstetricians listened for the reassuring sound of a fetal heartbeat and felt a woman's abdomen to monitor fetal growth and position. It was, in essence, educated guesswork, trying to visualize the unborn baby without ever really seeing it. In the late 1970's, obstetricians started to see it all. New kinds of ultrasound machines revolutionized prenatal monitoring. For the first time, physicians, mothers and fathers could look at the fetus's beating heart and squiggling hands and feet. Expectant parents left the doctor's office with goodie bags, envelopes filled with early baby photos.

headline.main: Advances, and Angst, in a New Era of Ultrasound

docs.abstract: Ultrasound fetal monitoring is on verge of yet another revolution, with latest gadgets creating three-dimensional images of fetus and monitoring blood flow of fetal organs; another technique being studied may eventually reduce need for amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling to detect birth defects; widespread use of ultrasound is raising new questions about how much information expectant parents want and whether all those using ultrasound know what new images mean; photo (M)
